title: Birth of ARPANET
description: The ARPANET, funded by the U.S. Department of Defense, established the first network connection between computers at UCLA and Stanford, laying the foundation for the modern Internet.

title: Introduction of the Apple II
description: The Apple II, one of the first highly successful mass-produced personal computers, featured color graphics and an open architecture that spurred software development.

title: Release of the IBM PC
description: The IBM Personal Computer (PC) became the industry standard, with its open architecture allowing third-party hardware and software, shaping the PC market for decades.

title: Launch of the Macintosh
description: Apple's Macintosh introduced a graphical user interface and mouse to the masses, revolutionizing user interaction with computers.

title: Launch of the World Wide Web
description: Tim Berners-Lee publicly introduced the World Wide Web, enabling the sharing of information over the Internet through hypertext.

title: Founding of Google
description: Larry Page and Sergey Brin founded Google in a garage, creating a search engine that would dominate the web and expand into numerous technologies.

title: Founding of Facebook
description: Mark Zuckerberg launched Facebook from his Harvard dorm, which grew into the world's largest social network, changing how people connect online.

title: Introduction of the iPhone
description: Steve Jobs unveiled the iPhone, combining a phone, iPod, and internet communicator, sparking the smartphone revolution.
